infodynamics.utils

Class ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.utils.MeasurementDistribution
      • infodynamics.utils.AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
        • infodynamics.utils.ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution

  • public class ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution
extends AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
    Class to represent analytic distributions of info theoretic measurements under some null hypothesis of a relationship between the variables, where the distribution of a function of those information-theoretic measurements is a Chi Square distribution. Can represent an analytic distribution of raw estimates or bias corrected estimates.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected ChiSquaredDistribution chi2dist
      An object of the chi2dist class from commons.math3, which we'll use to access the distribution values
      protected int degreesOfFreedom
      Number of degrees of freedom for the distribution
      protected boolean isBiasCorrected
      Tracks whether we will return a bias-corrected distribution or not
      protected double meanOfUncorrectedDistribution
      Stores the mean of the uncorrected distribution, useful for bias correction externally
      protected int numObservations
      The number of observations that the information theoretic estimate is computed from

    • Constructor Detail

      • ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution(double actualValue,
                                int numObservations,
                                int degreesOfFreedom)
        Construct the distribution. Note: the Chi squared distribution is technically of 2*numObservations*(the info theoretic estimate), not of the info theoretic measurement itself. This constructor assumes that we are not seeking a bias-corrected distribution.
        Parameters:
        actualValue - actual observed information-theoretic value
        numObservations - the number of observations that the information theoretic estimate is computed from
        degreesOfFreedom - degrees of freedom for the distribution

      • ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution(double actualValue,
                                int numObservations,
                                int degreesOfFreedom,
                                boolean isBiasCorrected)
        Construct the distribution. Note: the Chi squared distribution is technically of 2*numObservations*(the info theoretic estimate), not of the info theoretic measurement itself.
        Parameters:
        actualValue - actual observed information-theoretic value
        numObservations - the number of observations that the information theoretic estimate is computed from
        degreesOfFreedom - degrees of freedom for the distribution
        isBiasCorrected - whether to bias correct the distribution or not (and indeed whether the actualValue is bias corrected)

    • Method Detail

      • computePValueForGivenEstimate

        public double computePValueForGivenEstimate(double estimate)
        Description copied from class: AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
        Compute the analytic p-value for the given estimate (i.e. the input argument, not the estimate produced by any particular observations supplied) under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE as per the references below.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        • Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", Brazilian Journal of Probability and Statistics, 18, p. 163, (2004)
        • Cheng et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", Journal of Data Science, 4, p. 387 (2006).
        • Geweke, "Measurement of Linear Dependence and Feedback between Multiple Time Series", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 77, p. 304-313 (1982).
        • Barnett and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio", Physical Review Letters, 109, p. 138105+ (2012).
        Specified by:
        computePValueForGivenEstimate in class AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
        Returns:
        p-value for the given channel measure score under this null hypothesis.

      • computeEstimateForGivenPValue

        public double computeEstimateForGivenPValue(double pValue)
        Description copied from class: AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
        Compute the estimated observed measured value corresponding to a given p-value (derived from how the given estimates are analytically distributed under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value, possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE as per the references below.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        • Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", Brazilian Journal of Probability and Statistics, 18, p. 163, (2004)
        • Cheng et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", Journal of Data Science, 4, p. 387 (2006).
        • Geweke, "Measurement of Linear Dependence and Feedback between Multiple Time Series", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 77, p. 304-313 (1982).
        • Barnett and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio", Physical Review Letters, 109, p. 138105+ (2012).
        Specified by:
        computeEstimateForGivenPValue in class AnalyticMeasurementDistribution
        Parameters:
        pValue - the sample p-value for the given channel measure score under this null hypothesis.
        Returns:
        the estimate of the channel measure score corresponding to the given p-value under this null hypothesis.
